Evaluation_Questions: Overall, how would you rate the workload of this course in comparison to other Yale courses you have taken
What is your overall assessment of this course
What is your overall rating of the primary instructor
The primary instructor's provided students with helpful and timely feedback
The instructor established a positive learning environment
The instructor raised questions or problems that encouraged me to think critically
Comments_Questions: Indicate the total number of hours per week (outside the classroom) you spent on this course
Looking back on this course, what is your overall assessment of the course:  What are its strengths and weaknesses, and in what ways might it be improved
Please evaluate the instructor of this course. What are the instructor's strengths and weaknesses, and in what ways might his or her teaching be improved?
How would you summarize this course for a fellow student?  Would you recommend it to another student?  Why or why not
Comments_List: 2-3hours
around 3-4 hours per week
10 hours
10 hours
<5 on average
5-10 (depending on the assignment)
approximately 3-4 hours per week, sometimes longer if we had group meetings in addition to the work we did alone.
5 hours
Depended on the particular assignment and what we had due... anywhere between 5 - 20 or so.
3-4 (including group meetings)
Too many.
Between 5-10
There were 6 assignments in total, each requiring a good 10-20 hours of work, including meeting with team members, to complete.
5-6 depending upon if there was a section of the manual due that week
Course would benefit a lot from discussion and more interactive engagement during class meetings than lecture

There's a LOT of work, but you do get to make an intervention from start to finish. I wish there was more practicality in it -so basically we were forced to implement some part of it or something, so that we couldn't be so lofty in our intervention. I wish we did more intervention analysis on real interventions outside the research space (i.e. case studies) or campaigns, mobile interventions, hospital admin interventions etc which would have helped students who are not necessarily entering the research or non-profit space.

Strengths: The end product of the course, the intervention manual, is an incredible accomplishment. I'm proud of it and am grateful that we got interim, timely feedback on each section.

Improvements: the lectures themselves were not that helpful in my opinion. The slides didn't keep my attention. I really enjoyed the exercise we did where we got into groups to discuss outcomes evaluation strategies. I think those exercises are much more effective to retain knowledge than dry lectures. I would break into groups every class to discuss the topic of that day.
More in-class time to work in groups

I think it is a great course for people who are interested in intervention design, but I don't think that is everyone in SBS. 
I don't think it should be a requirement for the department, there were other classes I wish I had the opportunity to take in place of this one. 

That said, I think it was a well organized and instructive course. I just struggled to be really engaged with the content as it is not an area of public health I will be involved with in my career.

This course was a great experience for me. Very helpful to put into practice so many of the things that we've learned over the last two years, especially with most of the SBS cohort in one room and in formats that we'll likely be working with in the future. The tough feedback from Trace and Mahaya is excellent - I'm very grateful for that, and always want to be told when I'm wrong. 

The major negative was that some of the classroom sessions where the entire class was giving feedback were a little harsh - people were very sharp, and not respectful. I was surprised by this. I know it's a competitive and critical group, and the feedback is absolutely necessary, but the classroom environment could have been managed a little better in that respect.
Its great.

Strengths: similar to a capstone project, this course allows students to use the skills they have learned throughout the MPH program and put them all together to create an intervention. I really liked how this course allows students to be innovative, while challenging them to think critically and thoroughly evaluate and research the problem they're looking at.
Weaknesses: it's group project based, which can always have issues. Having more structure and support for how groups should handle the workload would be good. There was also a lot of overlap in assignments, so making the guidelines for each assignment more distinct could help solve this.

Strengths:
- What I expect SBS students to consider doing post-grad, so it was nice to have a taste of that firsthand
- Really interesting projects
- Sweet to have one last class with other SBS students
- Open to non-SBS students, which brought differing perspectives

Weaknesses:
- Experience of the course highly dependent upon group members
A bit lengthy at times and very easy to zone out.
I feel that it is a good course, and it teaches a good skill

Strengths: It does what is says on the box. I feel confident that I could design a health promotion.
Weaknesses: Lots of writing and revising, sometimes the feedback wasn't easy to understand/we didn't quite know what Prof. was wanting us to change

Strengths: Teaches about the importance of attention to detail, teamwork, and critical thinking regarding what determinants can be influenced and how (oftentimes with the realization that interventions are an iterative process and changing these determinants is not that simple)

Weaknesses: A lot of work, the lecture itself could be much shorter given the practical nature of the course

Strengths: You really know the best methods for developing a health promotion intervention
Weaknesses: Would recommend that first years take this class. It is difficult to balance this coursework while also completing a thesis.

Pretty poor. Did not like this class. It was a comprehensive class, but too much work. Honestly seemed to be an aggressive amount of work producing something that will never get used in the real world.
This course was a lot of work. It felt almost like a second thesis, but it was the most practical course of my MPH.

It was nice to have feedback throughout the intervention development process, but I don't particularly feel like I learned any new methods or approaches to public health research or practice. This might also be because as a second-year, I'd already taken several methods classes, and so it just seemed that we were applying them in a slightly different way.

This class does a good job of breaking up an entire intervention into manageable parts. I think it would be nice to have an overview of every section (1 class describing each section overview) and then go more in-depth for each class.

This course provided an opportunity to fully engage with intervention and evaluation concepts. Although it being theoretical had a number of advantages and drawbacks, the chance to create an intervention from scratch allowed me to learn the amount of thought and planning involved in creating an intervention.

Strengths - I did not know much previously about interventions and ways in which to evaluate them (both process and outcomes). That was extremely helpful and helped me to think about other courses/ programs in a different light. 

Weaknesses - I feel like this either needs to be a real life partnership with an actual CBO or group, or alternatively a hypothetical project with a non-vulnerable (e.g., students, faculty) group as the intervention target. It felt uncomfortable talking to CBOs about a hypothetical project that was not even possible to deliver to them. It just felt weird.
For second year SBS students, I would make this class a substitute for the thesis
good. only recommendation would be to not cover topic discussed in other SBS courses, such as Questionairre Development and Program Evaluation
Great instructor
great professor! makes class enjoyable
Trace is amazing. He's so laid back and allows students (for once) think for themselves and offer their own thoughts and opinions. His teaching style is my favorite at YSPH.

Strengths: Trace is a thoughtful, caring, and invested professor. It's so clear that he cares about our learning experience.

Improvements: Trace's lecture style is pretty dry and it affected the amount of information I was able to retain. The subject matter itself is dry, so it would help if Trace came up with a way to not just lecture on it, but do something else like my breaking into groups more often idea from above, or something even more impactful.
Enjoyed the last day of class when we could work in groups
Trace is a great professor. I think he achieves a great balance of being relaxed and approachable but still professional and knows his stuff.
Trace is great. I love his style, he has so much good experience. I really have a ton of respect for him and his teaching methods.
Hes an amazing professor. I learned so much!
Trace is a fabulous instructor! He's an expert in developing interventions, and is a great resource for students. He makes class fun and interactive. Overall, a great professor to take a class with.
Sometimes sort of all over the place.
Prof. Kershaw was very approachable and friendly, very knowledgeable on the subject matter. I appreciated how willing he was to answer questions and entertain different perspectives.

Approachable, knowledgable, laid back teaching style
May help to be a little more specific with feedback/check back for understanding so that students/instructor are on the same page with what is expected for assignments

Trace was great to learn from, especially given his wealth of experience. Nothing but positive things to say, aside from grading -- his point system (e.g., -0.3, etc.) felt a little arbitrary, at times (though he was thorough in and timely with feedback). Wonderful course, wonderful instructor.

Trace is the man, he is very good at creating a collaborative environment. However, the class feels off balance sometimes as only a few people are very engaged and ask questions that don't necessarily pertain to the class which take away class time .
He provides very thorough feedback that you could you in his course, and also in other courses at YSPH. He is also very encouraging!
Trace is a great guy and was very helpful throughout the semester, but it felt pretty obvious that Trace did not enjoy teaching this course.
Great!

Trace was great one-on-one, but lecturing is definitely not is strength. It was funny when the first hour of class was an ambling walk through some of the prepared slides, followed by group sharing that took up the rest of the time. We got work done, which was nice, but in terms of engaged teaching in the classroom setting? That wasn't really the case, but it didn't also need to be.
Trace is a great professor and is always willing to meet and provide feedback.
Trace is helpful and provides critical feedback. He explains concepts clearly and gives opportunities to engage in the material and is happy to meet with students.

Dr. Kershaw is clearly an expert in his field and does really amazing work, which I admire. But it did seem like he really was tired of teaching this class - understandable just unfortunate for our class.
Dr. Kershaw is very knowledgeable and very approachable.
Would recommend for anyone

If it's not a requirement and you want to go into another field, I would try to take something that's more critical. Creating the manual seemed redundant at times and excessive and not practical at times.

I highly recommend it on the basis that you get to design and write an entire intervention manual and think about every aspect of it. That's unique - you don't get to come out of a class with such an accomplishment typically. I recommend it to SBS and non-SBS students alike.
Would recommend to a fellow student

I would absolutely recommend this course to a student that was really interested in intervention design. 
However, I do with it was an optional course for SBS students and not a requirement.
The SBS capstone - critical for those who want to engage in public health practice/research!
Its great. Lots of work sometimes but sill a great learning experience

Yes, I would recommend this course if a student is interested in learning how to develop an intervention or new program, since this course allows you to methodically go through each step necessary in the development process. You'll definitely walk away knowing how to structure a research or intervention study, which is a great skill to have.
I think this course is a considerable amount of work but very enjoyable and Prof. Kershaw is a great teacher.

If your future involves designing and implementing health promotions- 100% recommended.

Word of warning, there is a lot of crossover with the Implementation Science class (which I had already taken) which made it somewhat less interesting for me. 

The whole class is based on group work so that may influence your decision. Choose your group and topic wisely to make your semester run smoothly.

Although it is a requirement for those of us in SBS, I would still recommend it to those who are not required because it truly lays the foundation for what a successful public health intervention entails.
First years - take it ASAP if it's still a requirement. Would not recommend this course if it is not required.
This is the unofficial SBS capstone. This makes the SBS department the actual most rigorous in terms of workload.
Although it is required for SBS students, it's also a great class for anyone who wants to systematically create an intervention for a specific population.
Overall the course was okay, it really is group dependent. Fortunately, I had a good solid group to work with.
This course is required for the SBS department. If you're interested in conducting and evaluating interventions in your professional career, you should take this class.
